channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Huge manhunt for Boston bomb suspect
item.description: Boston residents are urged to stay indoors as police search for a man suspected of bombing the city's marathon, as another suspect dies in a shoot-out.

item.title: Suspected measles death investigated
item.description: A death of a man is being investigated as part of the measles outbreak in the Swansea area of south Wales.

item.title: Rolf Harris in sex offence inquiry
item.description: Rolf Harris is the previously unnamed entertainer who was arrested by police as part of an inquiry into historical allegations of sexual offences.

item.title: Hamiltons settle phone-hacking case
item.description: Ex-Tory MP Neil Hamilton, his wife Christine, and former Blue Peter presenter John Leslie settle phone-hacking legal claims against the publishers of the News of the World.

item.title: Glaxo accused of market 'abuse'
item.description: The Office of Fair Trading accuses GlaxoSmithKline of paying rivals to delay the release of generic versions of one of its drugs.

item.title: Cameron war on council 'waste'
item.description: David Cameron has vowed to eradicate council "waste and propaganda" as he launched the Conservative local election campaign.

item.title: Pakistani police arrest Musharraf
item.description: Pakistan's former military ruler Pervez Musharraf is arrested on charges relating to the unlawful detention of judges in 2007.

item.title: Greens launch local election push
item.description: The Green Party of England and Wales launch their campaign for next month's council elections in England, stressing their opposition to welfare cuts and support for the green belt.

item.title: Extra marathon police to 'reassure'
item.description: The number of police officers on duty at Sunday's London Marathon is being increased by several hundred for "reassurance", Scotland Yard says.

item.title: Post Office staff set to strike
item.description: Thousands of staff plan to walk out of some of the UK's biggest post offices later in a dispute over shop closures, jobs and pay.

item.title: Farah hurt by money-grabbing claims
item.description: Double Olympic champion Mo Farah says he is running half of Sunday's London Marathon for the experience, not for the money.

item.title: River rescue lamb in legal wrangle
item.description: A newborn lamb which was saved from drowning after being rescued from a river is at the centre of a legal wrangle.

item.title: Lottery win couple plan eco-house
item.description: A young Nottinghamshire couple who won £45m in the Euromillions are planning to build a futuristic eco-house.

item.title: Santander might compensate 30,000
item.description: Santander, the country's second biggest mortgage provider, says 30,000 former Abbey customers may be due compensation, after errors made in 2008.

item.title: Online betting boosts William Hill
item.description: Bookmaker William Hill says online betting helped to boost first quarter operating profits, which rose by 8%.

item.title: MPs warn on London 2012 legacy
item.description: The volunteering spirit seen during the Olympic Games is in danger of "fizzling out", a group of MPs warns.

item.title: Britain needs 'new settlement'
item.description: Labour leader Ed Miliband is to tell Scottish Labour delegates there is need for change - comparable with that offered by Margaret Thatcher in the 1980s.

item.title: Call for minimum nursing levels
item.description: Minimum nursing staffing levels are needed to protect hospital patients from the impact of cuts in the NHS, a leading health union says.

item.title: Tameside is UK heart disease capital
item.description: There are "staggering inequalities" in deaths from heart disease in different parts of the UK, says a heart charity.

item.title: Tough inspection plan for nurseries
item.description: Nurseries and childminders in England are to face tougher inspections, the education watchdog Ofsted is expected to announce.

item.title: Lengthen school hours urges Gove
item.description: Schoolchildren in England should spend more hours at school each day and have shorter holidays, says Education Secretary Michael Gove

item.title: Cispa cyber bill passed by US House
item.description: The US House of Representatives has passed the controversial Cyber Information Sharing and Protection Act.

item.title: Sony hacker Recursion goes to jail
item.description: A 25-year-old has been sentenced to a year in prison for the part he played in hacking the website of Sony Pictures International in July 2011.

item.title: 'Most Earth-like' worlds detected
item.description: Scientists say Nasa's Kepler space telescope has found distant planets that may be the most Earth-like it has yet discovered.

item.title: Threat to Brazil tribe not lifted
item.description: The Brazilian government is accused of ignoring a legal deadline to remove settlers from the territory of a highly endangered tribe.

item.title: Tributes to Floyd artist Thorgerson
item.description: Pink Floyd drummer Nick Mason praises "tireless worker" album artwork designer Storm Thorgerson, who has died aged 69.

item.title: Matisse and Turner in new Tate shows
item.description: The Tate has announced a series of major retrospectives for the coming year, including exhibitions on Matisse, Turner and Mondrian.

item.title: The funeral's place in history
item.description: The funeral of Margaret Thatcher, which passed off more harmoniously than predicted, was an occasion rich in ironies, writes Dominic Sandbrook.

item.title: 1913: When Hitler, Trotsky, Tito, Freud and Stalin all lived in the same place
item.description: A century ago, a single square mile in the capital of the then Austro-Hungarian Empire was home to some of the most remarkable men of the 20th Century.

item.title: Raikkonen fastest in second practice
item.description: Lotus's Kimi Raikkonen heads the Red Bulls and Fernando Alonso's Ferrari in second practice at the Bahrain GP.

item.title: Carrick on Player of the Year list
item.description: Manchester United midfielder Michael Carrick is included on the shortlist for the PFA Player of the Year award.

item.title: GB's Whitlock wins European silver
item.description: Double Olympic bronze medallist Max Whitlock secures his first senior European medal with second place in the all-around in Russia

item.title: Lewis Hamilton: Racing is more strategic now
item.description: In his latest BBC Sport column, Lewis Hamilton talks about strategic racing and his car collection, as well as answering your questions

item.title: Man Utd will suffer jitters - Kidd
item.description: Manchester City first-team coach Brian Kidd says Manchester United's capitulation last season could affect their title bid.

item.title: Alert over nuclear plant groundwater
item.description: Groundwater at Dungeness B nuclear power station is found to contain a radioactive substance above agreed levels.

item.title: Driver run over and killed by coach
item.description: A 50-year-old coach driver dies after being run over by his own vehicle in a shop car park near Plymouth.

item.title: Green 'to depart' Rangers role
item.description: Charles Green has indicated to the Rangers board he is to leave his role as the chief executive of the club.

item.title: Sheriff court closure plans approved
item.description: Changes to the Scottish court system which will see 10 sheriff courts across the country closed are accepted by the Scottish government.

item.title: Killer jailed for hammer attack
item.description: A man must serve at least 16 years in jail for the murder of a Londonderry man in what a judge described as "unspeakable brutality".

item.title: Seven sentenced over drugs smuggling
item.description: Seven members of a gang are sentenced for their role in a drugs smuggling ring uncovered by police more than two years ago.

item.title: Death fire 'started deliberately'
item.description: A fire which killed five members of a family was started deliberately by someone holding a flame against a child's pushchair, says a fire expert.

item.title: Job hunter's race claim dismissed
item.description: An African-born man who accused Virgin Atlantic of racial discrimination after he applied twice for a call centre job has his case dismissed.

item.title: French Cameroon hostages freed
item.description: Seven members of a French family, including four children, abducted in northern Cameroon by suspected Nigerian Islamists are freed unharmed.

item.title: South Sudan army 'killed nurses'
item.description: Four nurses and a doctor were killed when South Sudan soldiers attacked a hospital in revenge for the killing of eight members of the security forces, the local MP tells the BBC.

item.title: Australian Olympic swimmers fined
item.description: Members of Australia's Olympic swimming team are fined and issued deferred suspensions for taking banned medication and misbehaviour.

item.title: 'Raped' Delhi girl in critical state
item.description: A five-year-old girl is battling for her life after being allegedly kidnapped and repeatedly raped by a neighbour in the Indian capital, Delhi.

item.title: Poland honours Jews who fought Nazis
item.description: Poland remembers the Jews who revolted against the Nazis in the Warsaw Ghetto uprising 70 years ago.

item.title: Lagarde warns UK growth 'not good'
item.description: The head of the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde, expresses renewed concern over the health of the UK economy.

item.title: Venezuela poll vote to be audited
item.description: Venezuela's election body announces it will carry out a full audit on all of the votes cast in Sunday's presidential election, as Nicolas Maduro prepares to be inaugurated.

item.title: Argentines rally against government
item.description: Tens of thousands of people in Argentina take part in protests against the government of President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner.

item.title: Clashes continue across Bahrain
item.description: Heavy clashes between anti-government protesters and security forces continue into the night in Bahrain, ahead of Sunday's F1 Grand Prix.

item.title: Mortar attack 'kills seven' in Iraq
item.description: At least seven people are killed in a mortar attack on a Sunni mosque in northern Iraq, police say, a day before provincial polls.

item.title: Search for survivors of Texas blast
item.description: Emergency services search for survivors after a deadly blast at a fertiliser plant in the US state of Texas, with firefighters among the missing.

item.title: Elvis impersonator on ricin charge
item.description: An Elvis impersonator from Mississippi is charged with sending a letter containing suspected ricin to US President Barack Obama.

item.title: In pictures: Boston police operation
item.description: US police search for suspect in deadly Marathon bombing

item.title: Day in pictures: 19 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 19 April

item.title: In pictures: Fertiliser plant blast
item.description: Explosion at a fertiliser plant near Waco

item.title: Your pictures: Migration
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme migration

item.title: In pictures: Stick men
item.description: Stick-men cards by Hannah Ensor

item.title: Day in pictures: 18 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 18 April

item.title: In pictures: Baroness Thatcher's funeral
item.description: Funeral of former UK PM Baroness Thatcher

item.title: Day in pictures: 17 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 17 April

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: A Conservative MP calls for a further cut in the top rate of income tax.

item.title: VIDEO: Hands on with Alonso's F1 simulator
item.description: BBC transport correspondent Richard Westcott tries out F1 driver Fernando Alonso's F1 simulator.

item.title: VIDEO: World's oldest person turns 116
item.description: The world's oldest person has celebrated his 116th birthday.

item.title: VIDEO: Veil of normality in Damascus
item.description: In parts of Damascus, life appears almost normal, but it is a different story towards the edges of the city, as the BBC's Jeremy Bowen reports.

item.title: VIDEO: Boston suspect killed during manhunt
item.description: US police are hunting a suspect in Monday's deadly Boston Marathon bombing in a small town near the city.

item.title: VIDEO: The Hoo's secret WWI trench warfare
item.description: Aerial archaeology has revealed a network of World War I trenches on the Hoo Peninsula which could rewrite military history.

item.title: VIDEO: Huge Chicago sinkhole swallows cars
item.description: A driver has been hospitalised after a huge sinkhole opened up in the middle of the street, swallowing three cars.

item.title: VIDEO: Female conductor in Proms milestone
item.description: The Last Night of The Proms is to be led by a female conductor for the first time in its 118 year history.

item.title: VIDEO: Golden couple's cup final surprise
item.description: Wigan Athletic manager Roberto Martinez hands FA Cup Final tickets to a couple who met following the club and are now celebrating their golden wedding.

item.title: Deepwater Horizon: Surviving the oil spill - interactive video
item.description: A new way to explore the story in video

item.title: A village in limbo
item.description: The community in limbo, with no police, bank or doctor

item.title: Rich List: Changing face of wealth
item.description: How the super rich have changed over the past 25 years

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: In what way is David Beckham getting posher?

item.title: Who, what, why: Why build a ship tunnel?
item.description: How is it possible to build a tunnel for large ships?

item.title: VIDEO: Meet the ebook evangelists
item.description: Will ebooks gobble up children's publishing?

item.title: A life lived in tiny flats
item.description: Is this enough space to live your life in?

item.title: The German Coronation Street
item.description: How does the German clone compare with the original?

item.title: Gove's school holiday plans debated
item.description: Gove's school holiday plans debated

item.title: Obama as warrior and healer
item.description: Obama has a tough task as innocents die, says Mark Mardell

item.title: App Pompeii - Museums on your phone
item.description: The museums offering exhibition access through your phone
